Award.AwardTitle: SHF: Small: High-Performance, Energy-Efficient Mobile Web Computing

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Web is continuously transforming society - shaping communications, catalyzing innovations, even shaping thought processes. Over the past decade, the role of the Web has shifted from information retrieval (Web 1.0) to providing a platform for interactive and engaging user experiences (Web 2.0). The Web is once again entering a new age, transcending user engagement to provide intelligent services that integrate multiple devices together. The driving force behind the Web's evolution is the ubiquity of mobile devices-undoubtedly today's most pervasive personal computing platform. The PI will study the crucial conjunction between mobile devices and Web technologies because mobile devices struggle to deliver high computational capability on a battery-power budget. The PI's integrated education plan, involving workshops, new curriculum and cutting-edge Web technologies, will stimulate students from a young age, who come from a diverse range of backgrounds, ethnicities, age groups and skill sets, to pursue academic interests in relevant scientific and technological fields. The exposure will nurture students to embrace careers in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics.

The research will lay the groundwork and establish the foundations needed to develop future high-performance and energy-efficient mobile computing systems that can usher in the next generation of Web applications.  The PI will research and investigate optimizations across the layers of the execution stack: at the (1) hardware layer the research will yield insights into new mobile processor architectures that achieve high efficiency by exploiting domain-specific and runtime knowledge; at the (2) runtime software layer, the project will lay the foundations for feedback-driven mechanisms that can dynamically learn to operate the architecture at energy-efficient points without compromising end-user application performance and user experience; at the (3) application layer, the research will discover language hints to empower application writers with awareness of their applications' energy consumption.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Web is continuously transforming society—shaping communications, catalyzing innovations, even shaping thought processes. Over the past decade, the role of the Web has shifted from information retrieval (Web 1.0) to providing a platform for interactive and engaging user experiences (Web 2.0). The Web is once again entering a new age, transcending user engagement to provide intelligent services that integrate multiple devices together. The key driving force behind the Web’s evolution is the ubiquity of mobile devices—undoubtedly today’s most pervasive personal computing platform.


The study focused on the crucial conjunction between mobile devices and Web technologies. The proliferation of the mobile Web rests largely on the capabilities of the underlying hardware. Mobile devices struggle to deliver high computational capability on a battery-power budget to meet applications’ quality-ofservice (QoS) requirements. Moreover, each generation of devices is expected to compute faster, last longer and accommodate more peripherals into increasingly thin form factors. The proposed research will lay the groundwork and establish the foundations needed to develop future high-performance and energy-eﬃcient mobile computing systems that can usher in the next generation of Web applications. The unique value of the research is the involvement of synergistic cross-layer optimizations across the hardware, software and application layers to maximize system eﬃciency. Since the Web is emerging as an “ambient” application development platform, the research has had impact at a very large scale.


The research provided optimizations across the layers of the execution stack: at the (1) hardware layer the research yielded insights into new mobile processor architecture to achieve high eﬃciency by exploiting domain specific and runtime knowledge; at the (2) runtime-software layer, the project laid the foundations for feedback-driven mechanisms that dynamically learn to operate the architecture at energy-eﬃcient points without compromising end-user application performance and user experience; at the (3) application layer, the research lead to the development of programming language hints to empower application writers with awareness of their applications’ energy consumption. 


In addition, the research involved hardware and software cross-layer collaboration to combine insights across the layers to design synergistic solutions to meet the next-generation’s mobile Web demand for performance without sacriﬁcing energy eﬃciency. In summary, the research lead to novel contributions across the diﬀerent layers of the computing stack, that advance state-of-the-art mobile devices and Web technologies, in the following diﬀerent but complementary ways:

  • Energy-eﬃcient, high-performance mobile cpu architecture delivering high performance without sacriﬁcing energy eﬃciency for web computing.
  • User-aware, feedback-directed runtime optimization and new scheduling algorithms for the architecture that bring user awareness into the optimization to improve system eﬃciency.
  • Qos-aware, energy-eﬃcient language hints: find language extensions that programmers can provide to the runtime system and architecture to guide their execution towards better eﬃciency.
